reviewText:
Hover Junkers is fun and has some cool VR moments. The gun play is definitely original and will probably help define the genre as VR grows. It's really the social aspects that make this game though - feeling like you're really in a shoot out with other people, and making lewd gestures to each other in between rounds is pretty awesome. However I thnk the $35 price tag and other reviews are misleading.

This is not a complete game. As much as I understand that VR is in its infancy and having something now is better than nothing, this game being stamped with a 1.0 version number is kind of insulting. Here's a short list of why:

- There are no tutorials to teach you anything about the game. The closest attempt is a practice range which tells you how to switch your weapons and reload. It is funny watching people play for the first time and struggle to figure out movement though.
- There are only two guns. Come on...
- Bugs. Half the time I played I wasn't able to control my hover thingy and would suddenly appear on top of another player. What's funny is everyone's characters had no lag at all - only our junkers did.
- No depth. Once you get past the novelty of ducking and shooting, that's about it. I don't see any point right now in collecting junk other than replacing pieces you lose. There's a vacuum that adds to your loot score when you put scrap it in, but the scoring in the game is so ambiguous I felt like giving it junk was actually hurting my score. Anyway, really there just needs to be more to do in the game - more weapons, environment stuff to interact with, or game modes.

I'm still recommending the game because I think what is there in the game is fun and that it's important to support the devs who are taking the first leap on this VR stuff. I felt like I had to write a review though that was a bit more honest than the marketing and other reviews are for this game.

Pay $35 to experience first person multiplayer VR shooting. Expect early access quality.

Very fun, fleshed out game.  Definitely needs more players!  Buy it now and we can shoot eachother!

EDIT:  Well, since I'm getting downvoted I suppose I'll elaborate.

This game is great.  The first time I took control of the ship and started moving, I was put off balance and almost fell over - not an exaggeration, and I'm not a clutz - it was that intense.  Now, of course, it's second nature and flying the ship is smooth and enjoyable.  During matches I often find myself just enjoying the scenery, flying around collecting junk (the non-aggressive way to score points, as opposed to killing other players) and getting into epic chases with other players.  The thrill of flying around actively dodging player's shots with both my body and my vehicle is indescribable.

Finding junk and properly using it to deck out your ship it is a game in and of itself, as different pieces of junk have different characteristics - they offer varying sizes, some offer slots to shoot through, and they all work independently of eachother.  Remembering which ones to slot together to form the best overall cover and offensive potential, while not required in the slightest, is rewarding just by itself.

Then there are the gun fights.  Effectively using your custom-constructed cover is rewarding and thrilling.  There are often holes in the cover that you have to be aware of and avoid / shoot through.

All of this praise being said, it's not without its flaws - but they are slight.  The hand interactions leave a bit to be desired compared to a lot of the other games of its kind (obviously Job Simulator comes to mind), but they're not too terribly bad, and it's really only prevalent in the bar-room, which is just a menu anyway.

Hopefully my longer critique has been helpful for you in making your purchasing decision.  I was hesitant about shelling out the money at first - I thought it looked lame, the characters were clunky, and that I wouldn't like flying around the ship.  All of that was proven so very wrong after just minutes of play.  Do yourself a favor and get it.

Probably one of the best VR games right now. It's like playing Airsoft/Paintball in your room against a bunch of people online. I found myself ducking behind cover and even crawling on the ground to find the perfect spot to shoot the enemy from.

What's really cool is the fact that they have different sized ships. My room isn't much of a looker when it comes to size (3m x 1,7m) and therefore I was scared at first to completely trash my furniture while playing. BUT they simply give you a ship fitting to your room size so you never have to worry about that. Naturally I don't want to walk against my ship's walls and that's really cool - it just feels so natural. So I'd say the controlls and movement and all that stuff is a solid 10/10.

The gameplay is something I've never seen before. I hope there will be more VR multiplayer shooters in the future because I truly believe this is what gaming will eventually become. It is so much fun, videos can't do it justice. At the beginning of each round you select your weapon of choice (although you can switch anytime between the pistol and the shotgun) and place some barricades around your ship for cover. And then you are good to go - kill everything that moves (although you should check for teammates first).

There is a basic ranking system in the game but it doesn't really have a purpose. You don't unlock weapons or anything with a higher rank. But it comes with a bunch of cool stats.

There are ~10 ships (maybe a bit more or less), 2 weapons and roughly 15 maps I want to say. Yes content is a bit short but the devs already have two new weapons in the making and promise regular updates.

In my opinion this is one of the few MUST HAVE games if you have a VR headset. I've never experienced something like it before. And by the way, this is the best way to exercise. After playing a few matches I had to stop because my legs hurt so much.

Get it! Now!

reviewText:
Fantastic fun, the priciest but most replayable VR title right now, being a multiplayer VR game.

Your first match in this game will definitely be very intense, it feels super cool and unlike any other VR game I've tried, because you're actually against another person. Seeing other people actually moving like a human makes it feel a lot more immersive and adds a lot of character to the game. There is a sort of social element to this with all of the hand gestures, and stuff like that. It can be really funny to lay down your weapons and mess around with the hand gestures and do stupid stuff, because everyone is so life-like. The social element is really a huge positive for this game.

This game does have a very short honeymoon phase as there isn't a big depth of content, but for my first couple matches it really felt like I was playing the coolest game ever. As you get used to it, it does start to feel quite same-y but the game is still fun and my favourite VR game right now.

I was skeptical from claims about price being too high and lack of content, and I will say that is kind of fair enough, not many weapons right now, stuff like that, but the core gameplay is amazing fun, and the developers are working with community feedback on steam and reddit to provide good updates, like the SMG that is about to be added. I look forward to seeing the game grow, and the singleplayer oregon-trail mode that is planned sounds pretty neat.

Living in Australia lag was fairly noticeable sometimes in matches, but nothing too bad. And while player counts for this game are low, there is always a match available to hop into and you only need 3+ people for it to be good fun. Although I have yet to try the team co-op mode due to only finding FFA matches.

As for performance, this game actually ran surprisingly great for me. Seeing the recommended 970 and 980 was worrying me, but it wasn't too bad even on my 7950 3gb, a card from 2012. If you hold alt while starting the game you can turn down the desktop window resolution and in-game, you can put the graphics down to 'debug' or lower than low. I found the game running surprisingly well with only an occasional fps drop. I also had interleaved reprojection off.


So in short, it runs pretty nicely, no trouble finding a match, social element and VOIP is great fun, very replayable, combat and taking cover is intense, and you can be excited for future updates to come and watch the game grow.

Definitely my favourite VR title, multiplayer puts it on a whole new level.

EDIT: I have since tried team/co-op mode, and it's really cool. It's good fun to interact with a ship crewmate, and shake hands and do silly stuff. Taking turns driving and duel wielding is pretty cool and there's a very social feel where it feels like your teammate is really with you.

reviewText:
This game absolutely accomplishes what it set out to do - a multplayer VR shootout in a space western setting. The visercal feeling of exchanging gunfire with another person in VR is something that really makes this game special.

The junk acts as a functional resource to incentivize movement around the map. The game starts with only a few pieces of junk onboard which won't cover the entire ship. Clever players will manuver themselves to exposed flanks, punishing unfortified ships.

Some of the controls feel very natural, but others are harder to divine. To steer the ship, grab the steering column and tilt in the desired direction. Easy and responsive. To switch to team voice chat, change the channel on the welder to channel 2. A little less obvious. After a couple hours in the game, the controls are no longer an issue.

There are crashes here and there (mostly between matches), but noticably less so from patch to patch. My experience was purely on the United States servers, with the game and networking feeling very responsive the vast majority of the time. Finding a game has never been a problem. On a given weeknight, the US playerbase has been ~40, with weekends seeing 60+.

I recommend favoring Team Deathmatch over Free-For-All for two reasons. First, the shootouts are more controlled than chaos; team-members open the door to more flanking strategies and yield less instances of being surronded and gunned down from behind. Second is the simple joy of riding shotgun with another player ; chase sequences and shooting side by side with another person are some of the best moments in this game.

A whole lot of fun and handily worth the price.

After seeing a few rather misleading negative reviews I thought I'd write my own.

Hover junkers is simply one of the best games I've played in VR. Where as other experiences have been just that - experiences - Hover Junkers is something I could see myself playing far into the future a bit like a VR overwatch or TF2.

I'll start with performance and networking issues. I've had none apart from some lag with is to be expected as my connection isn't the greatest, but as with any PC game in the immortal words of out lord and saviour TotalBiscuit individual mileage may vary.

Shooting is both intuitive and fun provided you're a good shot, but most of all it's emergent. Shooting it feels extremely real (coming from someone who has never actually shot a gun). It's a feeling which is difficult to explain to someone because it's something which has to be experienced first and foremost. But if you've ever had a airsoft shoot-out with a friend, it feels a bit like that, but dialled up to 11. With a flare gun. Some of the tactics you can pull are amazing.

What I mean by emergent is best explained like this. After playing Hover junkers for a couple of hours I started trying new thing rather than just rolling up one someone and shooting each other in the face until someone comes out on top. Things like blind-fire. Blind fire is not really a concept in a stand FPS because there is no way to really move your gun so to speak, it's only really applicable in TPS. But in hover junkers it is, if you're not making headway in a duel, a good way to catch someone out is to shoot over their cover from your own (Something where being tall gives you an advantage). The other thing I've found out is two hands are a lot more steady than one. At times I've been able to make distance shots by actually dropping a controller and letting it hang on my wrist while using both hands on a single controller. I've jety to try my Gun Kata skills yet though. This is something that actually works, when I first tried these things it just blew my mind. I'm no Tequila Yuen (the wires wouldn't allow for it), this game goes some way to making me feel like I am

I'm not even going to start on co-op game-play because I've not experienced that much of it. But I have both shed tears over the limp bodies of my co-op partners and taken my revenge with hot lead.

That sort of game-play is something you just don't get out of a standard shooter like CS:GO.

It's strange, and nothing on the market really compares or competes.

The only other thing I wanted to mention is the fun that can be had in lobby, which is quite strange, usually in a game you'll just sit for a bit looking at stats, but in over Junkers you're dumped in a room with the people you were just trying to kill. And although they're floating hands and headsets you do feel like you're in a room with other people. It promotes this strange sense of comradery as you pelt Gunther (Voice by Justin Justin Roiland aka Morty off Rick and Morty) with various objects from around the bar.

Oh, and if you haven't found it yet there's a makeshift hoop you can throw objects in for points.

In conclusion. Fantastic game, although a little bare bones which I've no doubt will be solved improved upon in further updates, nothing is more exhilarating than rolling up on a fool and shooting him or her in the face with a revolver. Or two. Or a shotgun.

reviewText:
While the shooting range felt really nice (the gun reloading was really fun), as soon as I entered an actual game I lost all immersion.  It seemed like a cool idea, room scale on a virtually moving platform, but the platforms (junkers) move too rigidly, can't turn (strafing only, collisions don't even rotate them), don't interact in a physically meaningful way when they hit obstacles, and the movement controls for them are just weird and don't feel right to me.  They also partially clip through each other and the animations of other player's avatars could really use a little more interpolation to counteract the all too prevalent network latency.

I probably would have given it another chance but the unnatural (IMHO) movement of the junkers was beginning to make me mildly nauseas, which is rare for me even in VR (been using VR for 3 years), so I went for a refund.  If they'd moved more realistically (based on my subjective definition) and had maintained my immersion I don't think this would have been an issue for me.  And yes, this was all at a good framerate.  The devs are adding more features and there are some good ideas here, though I just wish they'd called it early access and worked out the jankiness in the base game before adding more guns and modes.

Also, just throwing this out there: most of my gripes are totally subjective, so if you're curious there's no reason not to give it a go.  They're an indy dev and could probably use your support. Remember, Steam will usually grant refunds for less than two hours playtime within 14 days of purchase (but don't take my word for it, read the policy yourself).  I just personally can't recommend this game, and I *really* wanted to like it, oh well.

It's exactly what I imagined in my head when having nerf gun fights in my house as a child. I really enjoy this game and highly recommend it if you have VR with tracked controllers.

The basic flow of the combat in this game involves driving up to somebody and then dodging and ducking behind cover and popping out and shooting (or endlessly blind firing shotguns). They have a nice mechanic in this game that causes your ship to go slower when it's near someone, so, thankfully, it's not really a game of circle strafing around an opponent and stepping over your cord and trying to hit rapidly moving targets. You CAN move around a bit when near somebody but you're limited from going quickly. I've only seen a few players who tend to try to constantly move around during a gunfight, but I'm not yet convinced that it's a great strategy.

It may feel like there's a few things missing right now (a tutorial being one of them), but they've been very clear in their messaging that they will be continuing to update this game.

reviewText:
Currently I do not recommend this game, it has two extremely large flaws.


The first one is the biggest. I think the developers of this game built it without ever testing a rectangular playspace. Currently, if you have a rectangular playspace, it will ALWAYS be 90 degrees off from the shape of ships in Hover Junkers. There is no way to fix this, besides making your playspace a tiny square. This is an extremely huge bug in my opinion, that severely limits my ability to enjoy the game. If the playable area was simply rotated 90 degrees, I could use almost every craft in the game. As it stands I can only use one or two.


The other issue is that the netcode and hit detection are horrible. The uzi bullets have tracers, and you can consistently watch tracers travel directly through an enemy model. Often times a player with bad ping will teleport all over the place. Couple that with a revolver that can kill you in two headshots (there is no reason to use any other weapon, the revolver is perfectly accurate, can be reloaded almost instantly, and has a faster time to kill than anything in the game. The shotgun is worthless, and the uzi takes almost an entire magazine to kill someone even if you hit every shot.) and you have an extremely frustrating multiplayer experience.


Perhaps my biggest issue with this game is that IT HAS NO REASON TO BE OUT OF EARLY ACCESS. All of these bugs, balance issues, and half-developed features are NOT indicative of a fully-released game that costs $35. I absolutely love this game, but for what I've received, and knowing that the developers have no motivation to fix these issues, I feel I have no choice but to request a refund. Maybe I will purchase the game again when its features actually merit its price. It was a huge mistake to bring this game out of early access.


I cannot recommend this game to anyone unless the developers address these issues. What is currently available is not worth anywhere near $35, and games that have much more content, many less bugs, and are still in early access cost less.


EDIT: By the way yes, I do agree with other negative reviews of this game. This is too little for too much and it has lots of problems that a finished game would not. I look forward to seeing improvements in the future but for now I am refunding the game.

I had high hopes for this game. I can't currently recommend this game and I'm debating if I want to get a refund or just hang onto it with the hopes that things will be improved. Review might change in the future, but for now I'm pretty frustrated with this game. I'm okay with not being the top player, but if I'm going to die repeatedly, I want to at least have fun while it's happening.

reviewText:
It's cool, but I don't think it lives up to the hype.

Hover Junkers is a multiplayer-only room-scale VR shooter where several players are placed into an arena where they fight in different ships that they select.  It's a pretty simple game so I'll get straight to the pros and cons:

Pros:
- WOW ITS VR
- Shooting is cool, reloading is interesting but not how I would have done it
- Multiplayer is not dead on arrival
- Placing ship parts for cover is neat

Cons:
- No real co-op
- No single player mode
- Only has an arena mode
- No way to orient your ship (makes fighting difficult if the other person comes at you head on)
- Fighting lacks depth - there are only two guns and the gimmick of ducking and shooting gets old.  If you are fighting two people at once you will always lose because everyone has access to the exact same tools.  And the shotgun is pretty useless given that the boundaries of two junkers will make sure you're always outside of its effective range.
- No progression - there is nothing to unlock.  You have all two guns when you buy the game.

Overall I think this is a great vive launch title.  Perfect for introducing people to mechanics that will be standard in the future.  It is a bit on the expensive side for what it offers, but you already bought a vive.  It will become irrelevant in a few years when every VR games has ducking and shooting.

Overall 7/10

The gameplay is great, the whole idea will definitely work, but the game feels very unfinished.

That happens even on Low presents with 0 AA and low Textures. Considering how important frame rates are, I wish more emphasis would be made on this before releasing a game. Gameplay Breakdown:
Full room-scale. Drive your junker around an arena by starting the engine with one hand, then tilting it in the direction your wish to travel. Build your defences around the edges of your junker to provide cover from enemy cover. Fight other players to secure loot and ultimately win the match. Dual wield two weapons, one in each hand to fight.

I was a bit hesitant about this game, let's face it, quite a few VR games are getting good ratings more because there isn't much to choose from rather than due to actually being all that good. Many are just meh, this one is actually really cool.

There are only a few issues that jump to my mind, so let's touch on those.

1) The playerbase is a little on the small size right now, but that will change as more people get their VIVEs.
2) There aren't enough guns. Which should be addressed in the future with new content coming in.
3) It takes *way* too much to actually kill someone. 4-5 direct shotgun blasts to bring someone down is excessive, particularily when you consider how much they can use cover to keep themselves alive. There is no reason for it to take so much to drop someone.

Still, ducking and dodging behind cover is just insanely fun. Finding those little openings where you can hit your opponents while keeping yourself shielded. It just feels so intense.

Engaging. Careful if you're playing ina small space. You'll probably unplug your headset a few times and slam some tables and walls. Most traditional game-like experience I've had in the vive. Plenty of development left on the game, but already more than worth the money.

Gameplay Breakdown:
Full room-scale. Drive your junker around an arena by starting the engine with one hand, then tilting it in the direction your wish to travel. Build your defences around the edges of your junker to provide cover from enemy cover. Fight other players to secure loot and ultimately win the match. Dual wield two weapons, one in each hand to fight.

A positive review, but more of a feedback to the devs review.

The gameplay is great, the whole idea will definitely work, but the game feels very unfinished.

The judder (miss frames) is brutal. Now I'm running the minimum spec machine (6600k @ 4.4GHz, R9 290 @ 1200/6200), but to get judder, even in the shooting range, something is wrong. That happens even on Low presents with 0 AA and low Textures. Considering how important frame rates are, I wish more emphasis would be made on this before releasing a game. In saying all this, It might be SteamVR, it might be Drivers, but other games are fine and this one is one of the worst offenders.

The in game UI seems a bit strange. Your interface with your ship being the strangest thing, I can never quite get my ship to start first time and then steering seems oddly implemented. When selecting guns, I have to look at the wireframe menu that appears, as sometimes the gun I want is directly down, and sometimes it is down and inwards. It just doesn't feel polished.

The platforms having a partially locked attitude seems a bit hack-ish. Maybe this solves some of the motion sickness issue, but it makes the gameplay slightly less engaging when you cant spin to utilise your junk.

It's hard to tell if the network stack is acting up or not. More often than not people are jerking around the world (like the dialup days), but this might be a server issue or just that we're playing with people from all over the globe. There's no way to tell my ping to server, so I'm in the dark when selecting a server.

Ultimately, it just feels like the game isn't quite ready for release. I think it will be great, but it needs some polish.

This game definitely needs better tutorials (o.k. there is a great tutorial in the shooting range that explains everything, make sure you watch it starting out) because you're thrown into the game with no idea of what to do except for some practice at the shooting range. Once you know the gist of what you need to do and practice until you know what buttons to hit and how to steer and shoot properly (as well as how to shield your ship), the game just clicks.
